options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: You are debugging a Linux system. A student wants to transfer raw data to a display module connected over SPI. Which of the following device files are they most likely to interact with?
question_texts: You are debugging a Linux system. A student wants to transfer raw data to a display module connected over SPI. Which of the following device files are they most likely to interact with?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following best explains the difference between user space and kernel space?
question_texts: Which of the following best explains the difference between user space and kernel space?

options.option_text: User space has full hardware access, while kernel space uses syscalls forprotection
Both user space and kernel space run with limited privileges
User space applications run with limited privileges and must use syscalls toaccess resources, while kernel space has full access to hardware and drivers
Kernel space is only used for storing user applications, while user spacehandles drivers
Block device
Character device
Network interface
Input device
It represents a directory with read, write, execute permissions for theowner,and read, execute permissions for group and others
It represents a regular file with full permissions for everyone
It represents a character device file with restricted access
It represents a block device with only read permission for the owner

questions.question_text_1: What is the purpose of the ELF file in the Renode setup?
question_texts: What is the purpose of the ELF file in the Renode setup?

options.option_text: To represent memory configuration.
To define the system bus topology.
It contains compiled instructions to be loaded and executed on the emulatedCPU.
To define device tree information.

questions.question_text_1: What is the function of the root filesystem (rootfs)?
question_texts: What is the function of the root filesystem (rootfs)?

options.option_text: It provides essential files and binaries needed for Linux to boot.
It stores only the kernel.
It represents hardware configuration.
It is used for storing simulation logs.

questions.question_text_1: The 'initramfs' (initial RAM filesystem) is loaded into memory to:
question_texts: The 'initramfs' (initial RAM filesystem) is loaded into memory to:

options.option_text: Provide basic executables before disk-based root FS is available.
Initialize hardware GPIOs.
Start the emulator.
Replace the kernel image.
To reduce the number of handshaking signals.
To allow the master to issue multiple read requests before data returns,enabling pipelined and out-of-order reads.
To ensure reads are always completed sequentially.
To simplify the arbitration logic inside the slave.
The master failed to assert the read address signal.
The slave ignored the address handshake.
The slave accepted the read address but has not yet produced the read data.
The read response channel is permanently stalled.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true about the difference between Bare-Metal and OS-based systems?
question_texts: Which of the following is true about the difference between Bare-Metal and OS-based systems?

options.option_text: Bare-Metal systems always use virtual memory, OS systems do not
OS systems provide multi-tasking and memory protection, Bare-Metal systemsdo not
Bare-Metal systems support device files and sysfs, OS systems do not
OS systems run a single program at a time, Bare-Metal supports multipleprocesses

questions.question_text_1: For a 16-bit memory-mapped peripheral with word-aligned registers, which register offsets are valid?
question_texts: For a 16-bit memory-mapped peripheral with word-aligned registers, which register offsets are valid?

options.option_text: Byte 0 and Byte 2
Byte 1 and Byte 3
Byte 0 and Byte 1
Byte 2 and Byte 3
When multiple software threads may read the same status registerconcurrently.
When software monitoring tools need to detect and automatically clear errorsupon inspection.
When software must explicitly acknowledge and control flag clearing.
When multiple flags must be cleared atomically using a single write operation.
